About BaseSet

Lluís Revilla

August Pi i Sunyer Biomedical Research Institute (IDIBAPS); Liver Unit, Hospital Clinic
lluis.revilla@gmail.com

24 July 2019

Source: vignettes/basic.Rmd
basic.Rmd

Abstract

Describes the background of the package, important functions defined in the package and some of the applications and usages.

Getting started

This vignette explains how to use the methods available in this package.

The BaseSets class

This is a basic example which shows you how to create a TidySet object, to store associations between genes and sets:

library("BaseSet")
gene_lists <- list(
    geneset1 = c("A", "B"),
    geneset2 = c("B", "C", "D")
)
tidy_set <- tidySet(gene_lists)
tidy_set
#>   elements     sets
#> 1        A geneset1
#> 2        B geneset1
#> 3        B geneset2
#> 4        C geneset2
#> 5        D geneset2

Metadata for each element and set can be added:

gene_data <- data.frame(
    stat1     = c( 1,   2,   3,   4 ),
    info1     = c("a", "b", "c", "d")
)

tidy_set <- add_column(tidy_set, "elements", gene_data)
set_data <- data.frame(
    Group     = c(      100,        200 ),
    Colum     = c(     "abc",      "def")
)
tidy_set <- add_column(tidy_set, "sets", set_data)
tidy_set
#>   elements     sets Group Colum stat1 info1
#> 1        A geneset1   100   abc     1     a
#> 2        B geneset1   100   abc     2     b
#> 3        B geneset2   200   def     2     b
#> 4        C geneset2   200   def     3     c
#> 5        D geneset2   200   def     4     d

The relations, elements, and sets slots can directly accessed using their getter methods.

relations(tidy_set)
#>   elements     sets fuzzy
#> 1        A geneset1     1
#> 2        B geneset1     1
#> 3        B geneset2     1
#> 4        C geneset2     1
#> 5        D geneset2     1
elements(tidy_set)
#>   elements stat1 info1
#> 1        A     1     a
#> 2        B     2     b
#> 3        C     3     c
#> 4        D     4     d
sets(tidy_set)
#>       sets Group Colum
#> 1 geneset1   100   abc
#> 2 geneset2   200   def

All the relations are inherently fuzzy

set.seed(4567) # To be able to have exact replicates
relations <- data.frame(sets = c(rep("A", 5), "B", "C"),
                          elements = c(letters[seq_len(6)], letters[6]),
                          fuzzy = runif(7))
fuzzy_set <- tidySet(relations)

Converting to other formats

It is possible to extract the gene sets as a list, for use with functions such as lapply.

(list_set <- as.list(tidy_set))
#> $geneset1
#> A B 
#> 1 1 
#> 
#> $geneset2
#> B C D 
#> 1 1 1
(list_set <- as.list(fuzzy_set))
#> $A
#>         a         b         c         d         e 
#> 0.2309186 0.7412554 0.1833834 0.4221682 0.5996399 
#> 
#> $B
#>         f 
#> 0.2773313 
#> 
#> $C
#>         f 
#> 0.7307312

It is also possible to visualize membership between gene and gene sets as a matrix.

Notably, incidence return a numeric matrix of membership:

(incidence_matrix <- incidence(tidy_set))
#>   geneset1 geneset2
#> A        1        0
#> B        1        1
#> C        0        1
#> D        0        1
(incidence_matrix <- incidence(fuzzy_set))
#>           A         B         C
#> a 0.2309186 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> b 0.7412554 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> c 0.1833834 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> d 0.4221682 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> e 0.5996399 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> f 0.0000000 0.2773313 0.7307312

Converting from other formats

Conversely, it is also possible to make objects from incidence matrices.

Notably, BaseSets are suitable for numeric matrices indicating membership:

tidySet(incidence_matrix)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        a    A 0.2309186
#> 2        b    A 0.7412554
#> 3        c    A 0.1833834
#> 4        d    A 0.4221682
#> 5        e    A 0.5996399
#> 6        f    B 0.2773313
#> 7        f    C 0.7307312

Or can also be created from lists:

tidySet(list("A" = letters[1:4], "B" = letters[7:10]))
#>   elements sets
#> 1        a    A
#> 2        b    A
#> 3        c    A
#> 4        d    A
#> 5        g    B
#> 6        h    B
#> 7        i    B
#> 8        j    B

Additional information

The number of unique elements and sets can be obtained using the nElements and nSets methods.

nElements(tidy_set)
#> [1] 4
nSets(tidy_set)
#> [1] 2
nRelations(tidy_set)
#> [1] 5

The size of each gene set can be obtained using the set_size method.

set_size(tidy_set, "geneset1")
#>       sets size probability Group Colum
#> 1 geneset1    2           1   100   abc
set_size(fuzzy_set, "A")
#>   sets size probability
#> 1    A    0 0.037593610
#> 2    A    1 0.080805868
#> 3    A    2 0.278302802
#> 4    A    3 0.384150899
#> 5    A    4 0.211200558
#> 6    A    5 0.007946263

Conversely, the number of sets associated with each gene is returned by the elementLengths function.

element_size(tidy_set)
#>   elements size probability stat1 info1
#> 1        A    1           1     1     a
#> 2        B    2           1     2     b
#> 3        C    1           1     3     c
#> 4        D    1           1     4     d

The identifiers of elements and sets can be inspected and renamed using name_elements and

name_elements(tidy_set)
#> [1] "A" "B" "C" "D"
name_elements(tidy_set) <- paste0("Gene", seq_len(nElements(tidy_set)))
name_elements(tidy_set)
#> [1] "Gene1" "Gene2" "Gene3" "Gene4"
name_sets(tidy_set)
#> [1] "geneset1" "geneset2"
name_sets(tidy_set) <- paste0("Geneset", seq_len(nSets(tidy_set)))
name_sets(tidy_set)
#> [1] "Geneset1" "Geneset2"

Operations with sets

To work with sets several methods are provided. All methods work with fuzzy and non-fuzzy sets

Union

By default it provides the standard union, but you can provide a function.

union(fuzzy_set, sets = c("C", "B"), name = "D")
union(fuzzy_set, sets = c("C", "B"), name =  "D", FUN = "mean")
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        f    D 0.7307312
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        f    D 0.5040313

Intersection

intersection(fuzzy_set, sets = c("A", "B"), name = "D", keep = TRUE)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        a    A 0.2309186
#> 2        b    A 0.7412554
#> 3        c    A 0.1833834
#> 4        d    A 0.4221682
#> 5        e    A 0.5996399
#> 6        f    B 0.2773313
#> 7        f    C 0.7307312

Complement

We can look for the complement of one or several sets:

complement_set(fuzzy_set, sets = c("A", "B"))
#>    elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1         a    A 0.2309186
#> 2         a ∁A∪B 0.7690814
#> 3         b    A 0.7412554
#> 4         b ∁A∪B 0.2587446
#> 5         c    A 0.1833834
#> 6         c ∁A∪B 0.8166166
#> 7         d ∁A∪B 0.5778318
#> 8         d    A 0.4221682
#> 9         e    A 0.5996399
#> 10        e ∁A∪B 0.4003601
#> 11        f    B 0.2773313
#> 12        f    C 0.7307312
#> 13        f ∁A∪B 0.7226687

Subtract

This is the equivalent of setdiff, but clearer:

subtract(fuzzy_set, set_in = "A", not_in = "B", keep = FALSE)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        a  A∖B 0.2309186
#> 2        b  A∖B 0.7412554
#> 3        c  A∖B 0.1833834
#> 4        d  A∖B 0.4221682
#> 5        e  A∖B 0.5996399
subtract(fuzzy_set, set_in = "B", not_in = "A", keep = FALSE)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy
#> 1        f  B∖A 0.2773313

tidyverse

You can also use mutate, filter and other dplyr verbs with TidySets (with the only exception being group_by):

library("dplyr")
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:BaseSet':
#> 
#>     union
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
fuzzy_set %>% 
  activate("relations") %>% 
  mutate(Important = as.numeric(fuzzy > 0.5))
#>   elements sets     fuzzy Important
#> 1        a    A 0.2309186         0
#> 2        b    A 0.7412554         1
#> 3        c    A 0.1833834         0
#> 4        d    A 0.4221682         0
#> 5        e    A 0.5996399         1
#> 6        f    B 0.2773313         0
#> 7        f    C 0.7307312         1

You can use activate to select what are the verbs modifying:

set_modified <- fuzzy_set %>% 
  activate("relations") %>% 
  mutate(Important = as.numeric(fuzzy > 0.5)) %>% 
  activate("elements") %>% 
  mutate(Pathway = if_else(elements %in% c("b", "f", "g"), 
                           "pathway1", 
                           "pathway2"))
set_modified
#>   elements sets     fuzzy Important  Pathway
#> 1        a    A 0.2309186         0 pathway2
#> 2        b    A 0.7412554         1 pathway1
#> 3        c    A 0.1833834         0 pathway2
#> 4        d    A 0.4221682         0 pathway2
#> 5        e    A 0.5996399         1 pathway2
#> 6        f    B 0.2773313         0 pathway1
#> 7        f    C 0.7307312         1 pathway1
set_modified %>% 
  deactivate() %>% # To apply a filter independently to where it is
  filter(Pathway == "pathway1", Important == 1)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy Important  Pathway
#> 1        b    A 0.7412554         1 pathway1
#> 2        f    C 0.7307312         1 pathway1

If you want to use group_by to group some elements then you need to create a new set:

# A new group of those elements in pathway1 and with Important == 1
set_modified %>% 
  deactivate() %>% 
  group("new", Pathway == "pathway1", Important == 1)
#>   elements sets     fuzzy Important  Pathway
#> 1        a    A 0.2309186         0 pathway2
#> 2        b    A 0.7412554         1 pathway1
#> 3        b  new 1.0000000        NA pathway1
#> 4        c    A 0.1833834         0 pathway2
#> 5        d    A 0.4221682         0 pathway2
#> 6        e    A 0.5996399         1 pathway2
#> 7        f    B 0.2773313         0 pathway1
#> 8        f    C 0.7307312         1 pathway1
#> 9        f  new 1.0000000        NA pathway1

After grouping or mutating sometimes we might be interested in moving a column describing something to other places. We can do by simplify:

elements(set_modified)
#>   elements  Pathway
#> 1        a pathway2
#> 2        b pathway1
#> 3        c pathway2
#> 4        d pathway2
#> 5        e pathway2
#> 6        f pathway1
out <- move_to(set_modified, "elements", "relations", "Pathway")
relations(out)
#>   sets elements     fuzzy Important  Pathway
#> 1    A        a 0.2309186         0 pathway2
#> 2    A        b 0.7412554         1 pathway1
#> 3    A        c 0.1833834         0 pathway2
#> 4    A        d 0.4221682         0 pathway2
#> 5    A        e 0.5996399         1 pathway2
#> 6    B        f 0.2773313         0 pathway1
#> 7    C        f 0.7307312         1 pathway1
